variation_system.description: Chinese profanity variations including Traditional/Simplified characters, romanization systems, and internet evasion methods
variation_system.methodology: Based on Pinyin romanization, Traditional/Simplified character relationships, and creative censorship evasion

simplified_chinese.name: 简体中文 (Simplified Chinese)
simplified_chinese.description: Simplified character system used in Mainland China and Singapore

traditional_chinese.name: 繁體中文 (Traditional Chinese)
traditional_chinese.description: Traditional character system used in Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Macau
traditional_chinese.unicode_range: CJK Unified Ideographs and Extension blocks

pinyin.name: Pinyin (拼音)
pinyin.description: Official romanization system of Mainland China

草泥马.meme_context: Alpaca (羊驼) homophone for 'fuck your mother'

homophone_substitution.description: Using characters with similar pronunciation to avoid detection

examples.河蟹: hé xiè (river crab) for 和谐 (harmony/censorship)
examples.草泥马: cǎo nǐ mā (alpaca) for 肏你妈 (fuck your mother)
examples.雅蠛蝶: yǎ miè dié (butterfly) for やめて (yamete/stop in Japanese)

homophone_substitution.cultural_context: Often becomes internet meme with dual meaning

visual_character_replacement.description: Using visually similar characters or radicals

examples.艹: Grass radical (艹) instead of 操 (fuck)
examples.屮: Sprout radical (屮) as general profanity euphemism

visual_character_replacement.evolution: Characters gain profane meaning through visual association

alphabetic_substitution.description: Using Latin letters mixed with Chinese characters

examples.NB: 牛逼 (niú bī) meaning 'awesome' but containing profanity

alphabetic_substitution.typing_convenience: Easier to type on keyboards, harder to filter

emoji_and_symbols.description: Using emojis and Unicode symbols as character substitutes

examples.🐴: Horse emoji for 马 replacing 妈 (mother)

emoji_and_symbols.mobile_culture: Smartphone emoji keyboards enable creative expression

spacing_and_punctuation.description: Using spaces, punctuation, or special characters to break up words

number_substitution.description: Using numbers that look like or sound like characters

examples.250: 二百五 (èr bǎi wǔ) meaning 'stupid person'

number_substitution.cultural_numbers: Some numbers have inherent negative connotations

cantonese.unique_profanity: Many Cantonese profanity terms have no Mandarin equivalent

examples.屌: diu2 (Cantonese) vs diǎo (Mandarin), different usage patterns
examples.仆街: puk1 gaai1 (fall on street) Cantonese-specific curse

cantonese.character_sharing: Same characters may have different severity in different dialects

hokkien_taiwanese.historical_influence: Japanese colonial influence on profanity vocabulary
hokkien_taiwanese.local_context: Strong regional identity affects severity perception

shanghainese.urban_culture: Metropolitan culture creates unique slang patterns
shanghainese.generational_change: Younger generations increasingly use Mandarin profanity

classical_chinese_roots.description: Many insults derive from classical Chinese literature
classical_chinese_roots.examples: 畜生, 禽兽 from classical moral categories
classical_chinese_roots.cultural_weight: Classical origins give additional gravitas to insults

republican_era.description: Early 20th century political and social upheaval language
republican_era.examples: 走狗 (running dog), 汉奸 (traitor) from this period

cultural_revolution.examples: 牛鬼蛇神 (monsters and demons), 走资派 (capitalist roader)
cultural_revolution.ideological_language: Class struggle vocabulary as insult language

reform_era.description: Economic reform period creating new social tensions
reform_era.examples: 暴发户 (nouveau riche), 下海 (going into business)

internet_age.description: Digital culture creating new forms and evasion methods
internet_age.meme_evolution: Internet culture drives rapid language evolution

mainland_china.censorship_pressure: Heavy internet filtering drives creative evasion
mainland_china.political_sensitivity: Political terms heavily monitored and filtered
mainland_china.social_media_evolution: WeChat, Weibo usage patterns affect language

taiwan.japanese_influence: Historical Japanese rule affects some vocabulary
taiwan.democratic_expression: More open political expression affects language norms
taiwan.traditional_characters: Traditional character usage affects visual substitutions

hong_kong.cantonese_dominance: Cantonese profanity has different patterns from Mandarin
hong_kong.british_influence: Historical British rule affects some expression patterns

singapore.multilingual_environment: Chinese mixed with English, Malay in 'Singlish'

unicode_normalization.description: Different Unicode representations of same character
unicode_normalization.importance: Critical for accurate detection and filtering

font_variations.description: Same character may appear differently in different fonts
font_variations.detection_challenges: Visual similarity doesn't guarantee Unicode equivalence
font_variations.regional_fonts: Regional font preferences affect character appearance

input_methods.description: Different input methods create different typing patterns
input_methods.pinyin_ime: Mainland China standard, affects abbreviation patterns
input_methods.zhuyin_ime: Taiwan standard, creates different shorthand patterns
input_methods.handwriting_recognition: Mobile handwriting creates new variation patterns

machine_translation.description: Translation services often struggle with profanity context
machine_translation.censorship_interaction: Some services automatically censor or modify profanity
